üíæ Presets & Scenes Guide

System Overview

The RGLR GNRTR uses a two-tier system for saving and organizing your visual configurations:

Key Differences:
  • Presets: Save specific parameter groups (MIDI mappings, animation settings, etc.)
  • Scenes: Save complete visual configurations including all settings and layers

Presets vs Scenes

üéõÔ∏è Presets

  • Purpose: Focused collections of related parameters
  • Scope: Specific aspects like animation controls, lighting, or materials
  • Use Case: Building blocks for creating complex visuals
  • Flexibility: Mix and match multiple presets
  • Examples: "Essential Controls", "Grid Composition", "Visual Effects"

üé¨ Scenes

  • Purpose: Complete visual configurations
  • Scope: Everything - all parameters, layers, MIDI mappings
  • Use Case: Complete compositions for specific songs or moods
  • Flexibility: One-click complete visual setups
  • Examples: "RGLR Mode", "Globules", "Matcha Mode"

Workflow Integration

  • Start with Presets: Load presets to quickly configure specific aspects
  • Customize: Adjust parameters for your specific needs
  • Save as Scene: Save complete configurations for later use
  • Live Performance: Switch between scenes for different songs/sections

üéõÔ∏è Preset System

Presets are curated collections of parameter settings that focus on specific aspects of the visual system. They're designed to be mixed and matched to create complex configurations quickly.

Preset Categories

  • Control Presets: MIDI mappings and essential controls
  • Composition Presets: Grid layouts and structural settings
  • Animation Presets: Movement, rotation, and timing configurations
  • Visual Presets: Effects, lighting, and materials
  • Transition Presets: Morphing and shape cycling settings

How Presets Work

  • Selective Loading: Presets only change specific parameters, leaving others untouched
  • Additive: You can load multiple presets to combine their effects
  • Non-Destructive: Loading a preset doesn't overwrite unrelated settings
  • Instant Application: Changes take effect immediately
Preset Loading Strategy:
  1. Start with Control Preset: Set up MIDI mappings first
  2. Add Composition Preset: Configure grid and layout
  3. Apply Animation Presets: Add movement and timing
  4. Enhance with Visual Presets: Add effects and lighting
  5. Fine-tune: Adjust individual parameters as needed

üì¶ Available Presets

The system comes with carefully crafted presets designed by experienced visual artists and performers.

Essential Controls

Core MIDI mappings for live performance, including basic animation controls and essential parameters.

Includes: Movement, rotation, scale controls, BPM, color parameters

Grid Composition

Grid layout and structural settings for different composition styles and screen formats.

Includes: Grid dimensions, cell sizes, composition framing, randomness

Animation Movement

Comprehensive movement animation settings with musical timing and amplitude controls.

Includes: Movement patterns, timing divisions, amplitude mapping, sync settings

Shape Controls

Complete shape cycling and morphing system with easing curves and transition controls.

Includes: Shape cycling, morphing triggers, easing functions, timing

Lighting Materials

Professional lighting setup with multiple light sources and material configurations.

Includes: Light intensities, sphere materials, refraction, transparency

Visual Effects

Post-processing effects including bloom, chromatic aberration, vignette, and film grain.

Includes: Bloom settings, color grading, visual filters, cinematic effects

Morphing Transitions

Advanced morphing system with multiple trigger types and smooth easing curves.

Includes: Morphing triggers, easing curves, timing divisions, sync modes

Sample Multi-Channel

Example configuration showing how to use multiple MIDI channels and complex mappings.

Includes: Multi-channel setup, advanced mappings, performance examples
Preset Combinations:
  • Quick Start: Essential Controls + Grid Composition
  • Full Animation: Animation Movement + Shape Controls + Morphing Transitions
  • Cinematic Look: Lighting Materials + Visual Effects
  • Performance Setup: Essential Controls + Sample Multi-Channel

üéÆ Using Presets

Loading and managing presets is designed to be quick and intuitive for live performance.

Loading Presets

  1. Open Preset Panel: Click the preset icon in the left sidebar
  2. Browse Presets: Scroll through the available preset list
  3. Preview Information: Read the preset description and included parameters
  4. Load Preset: Click "Load" to apply the preset settings
  5. Observe Changes: Watch as parameters update in real-time

Preset Loading Behavior

  • Immediate Effect: Changes are applied instantly
  • Selective Update: Only parameters included in the preset are changed
  • Preserved Settings: Unrelated parameters remain unchanged
  • MIDI Mapping Integration: MIDI controls automatically connect to new parameters

Example Preset Loading Sequence:

  1. Start: Default/blank configuration
  2. Load "Essential Controls": MIDI mappings and basic controls are set up
  3. Load "Grid Composition": Grid layout is configured, MIDI mappings remain
  4. Load "Animation Movement": Movement animations are added to existing setup
  5. Result: Combined configuration with all three preset features

Live Performance Tips

  • Pre-load Favorites: Know which presets work well together
  • Quick Access: Keep the preset panel open for fast loading
  • Layer Gradually: Add presets progressively during builds
  • Reset Strategy: Know how to quickly return to baseline configurations

üé¨ Scene System

Scenes capture complete visual configurations, including all parameters, MIDI mappings, layer settings, and visual state. They're perfect for creating distinct looks for different songs or performance sections.

What Scenes Include

  • All Parameters: Every visual parameter and its current value
  • MIDI Mappings: Complete MIDI controller configuration
  • Layer Settings: P5 sketches, layer configurations, blend modes
  • Animation States: Current animation types and timing
  • Visual Effects: Post-processing settings and material configurations
  • Grid Configuration: Layout, dimensions, and structural settings

Scene Loading Behavior

  • Complete Replacement: Scenes overwrite all current settings
  • Instant Transformation: Entire visual changes immediately
  • State Preservation: Scenes remember exact configurations
  • Performance Optimized: Loading is fast for live use
Scene Loading Note: Unlike presets, scenes replace your entire configuration. Make sure to save your current work as a scene before loading a different one if you want to preserve it.

üé≠ Available Scenes

The system includes a variety of pre-designed scenes, each with a distinct aesthetic and purpose.

RGLR Mode

The signature RGLR GNRTR aesthetic - clean geometric patterns with smooth animations and professional lighting.

Style: Minimal, geometric, professional ‚Ä¢ Best For: Electronic music, clean visuals

Globules

Organic, fluid-like visuals with sphere materials and flowing movements. Creates liquid, bubble-like effects.

Style: Organic, fluid, refractive ‚Ä¢ Best For: Ambient music, organic aesthetics

Matcha Mode

Soft, natural color palette with gentle animations. Inspired by organic tea ceremony aesthetics.

Style: Soft, natural, calming ‚Ä¢ Best For: Acoustic music, meditation, relaxed settings

Meat Mode

Bold, intense visuals with strong contrasts and dramatic lighting. High-energy aesthetic.

Style: Bold, intense, high-contrast ‚Ä¢ Best For: Rock, metal, high-energy performances

Worm Mode

Flowing, segmented patterns that create worm-like or snake-like movements across the grid.

Style: Flowing, segmented, hypnotic ‚Ä¢ Best For: Experimental music, mesmerizing effects

Angles Mode

Sharp, angular geometry with precise movements. Emphasizes geometric patterns and mathematical precision.

Style: Angular, precise, mathematical ‚Ä¢ Best For: Techno, minimal music, geometric aesthetics

Forbidden Bubblegum

Playful, colorful aesthetic with bouncy animations and bright, saturated colors.

Style: Playful, colorful, bouncy ‚Ä¢ Best For: Pop music, fun performances, colorful shows

Scene Selection Guide

Music Genre Recommended Scenes Aesthetic Match
Electronic/Techno RGLR Mode, Angles Mode Clean, geometric, precise
Ambient/Chill Globules, Matcha Mode Organic, flowing, calming
Rock/Metal Meat Mode, Angles Mode Intense, bold, dramatic
Pop/Dance Forbidden Bubblegum, RGLR Mode Colorful, energetic, fun
Experimental Worm Mode, Globules Unusual, hypnotic, abstract

üéõÔ∏è Scene Management

Managing scenes effectively is crucial for smooth live performances and organized visual libraries.

Loading Scenes

  1. Open Scene Panel: Click the scene icon in the left sidebar
  2. Browse Available Scenes: View the scene list with descriptions
  3. Preview Scene Info: Read about the scene's style and purpose
  4. Load Scene: Click "Load" to switch to the complete scene configuration
  5. Immediate Effect: All visuals change instantly to match the scene

Scene Loading Performance

  • Fast Loading: Scenes load in < 100ms for responsive live use
  • Smooth Transitions: Visual changes are immediate but smooth
  • State Consistency: All parameters are perfectly synchronized
  • MIDI Integration: Controller mappings are instantly updated

Live Performance Scene Workflow:

  1. Pre-Show: Load your starting scene (e.g., "RGLR Mode")
  2. Song 1: Perform with current scene, use MIDI controls for variation
  3. Transition: Load new scene between songs (e.g., "Globules")
  4. Song 2: New aesthetic matches different musical style
  5. Build Section: Use MIDI controls to intensify current scene
  6. Dramatic Change: Load contrasting scene (e.g., "Meat Mode") for climax
Scene Organization Tips:
  • Plan Your Set: Choose scenes that complement your musical progression
  • Contrast is Key: Alternate between different aesthetic styles
  • Quick Access: Keep the scene panel open for fast switching
  • Practice Transitions: Rehearse scene changes to match musical cues

üõ†Ô∏è Creating Custom Presets

Custom presets allow you to save and share your own parameter configurations for specific use cases.

When to Create Presets

  • Specialized MIDI Setups: Your specific controller configuration
  • Signature Effects: Unique combinations of visual parameters
  • Performance Templates: Starting points for different types of shows
  • Collaboration: Share configurations with other performers
  • Workflow Optimization: Speed up your setup process

Preset Creation Process

  1. Configure Parameters: Set up the exact parameter values you want to save
  2. Test Configuration: Verify everything works as expected
  3. Open Preset Panel: Access the preset management interface
  4. Click "Save Preset": Initiate the preset creation process
  5. Choose Parameters: Select which parameters to include in the preset
  6. Name and Describe: Give your preset a clear name and description
  7. Save to File: Export the preset as a JSON file

Preset Design Best Practices

Parameter Selection Guidelines:

  • Focus: Include related parameters that serve a common purpose
  • Completeness: Include all parameters needed for the effect to work
  • Avoid Conflicts: Don't include parameters that might conflict with other presets
  • Consider Combinations: Think about how your preset will work with others

Naming Conventions:

  • Descriptive: "Bass-Responsive Scaling" rather than "My Preset 1"
  • Category: Include the type (e.g., "Animation - Wave Motion")
  • Purpose: Indicate use case (e.g., "Live Performance - Essential Controls")
  • Version: Include version numbers for iterations (e.g., "v2.1")

Preset File Management

  • File Location: Save presets in the public/presets/ directory
  • File Format: JSON format with .json extension
  • Backup: Keep backups of your custom presets
  • Sharing: Presets can be shared by copying JSON files
  • Version Control: Consider using git for preset libraries

üé¨ Creating Custom Scenes

Custom scenes capture your complete visual configurations for specific songs, moods, or performance contexts.

Scene Creation Process

  1. Perfect Your Configuration: Set up all parameters, MIDI mappings, and layers exactly as desired
  2. Test Thoroughly: Verify all animations, effects, and controls work correctly
  3. Open Scene Panel: Access the scene management interface
  4. Click "Save Scene": Initiate the scene creation process
  5. Name Your Scene: Choose a memorable, descriptive name
  6. Add Description: Document the scene's purpose and characteristics
  7. Save Configuration: Export the complete scene as a JSON file

Scene Design Philosophy

Complete Configuration Approach:

  • Holistic Design: Consider how all elements work together
  • Musical Alignment: Design scenes for specific musical styles or songs
  • Performance Context: Consider lighting, venue, and audience
  • Controller Integration: Ensure MIDI mappings support live performance

Scene Naming and Organization

Effective Scene Names:

  • Mood-Based: "Ethereal Dreams", "Industrial Storm", "Peaceful Garden"
  • Genre-Based: "Techno Minimalism", "Ambient Waves", "Rock Energy"
  • Song-Specific: "Track 1 - Opening", "Breakdown Section", "Finale"
  • Color/Style: "Blue Serenity", "Golden Hour", "Neon Nights"

Scene Documentation

  • Description: Explain the scene's aesthetic and purpose
  • Musical Context: Note what genres or moods it works best with
  • Key Features: Highlight special effects or unique elements
  • Performance Notes: Document any special performance considerations
  • MIDI Requirements: Note any specific controller requirements

Scene File Management

  • File Location: Save scenes in the public/scenes/ directory
  • File Format: JSON format with .json extension
  • Backup Strategy: Regularly backup your scene library
  • Version Control: Track changes to scenes over time
  • Performance Optimization: Keep scene files organized for quick access

üí° Workflow Tips & Best Practices

Maximize your efficiency and creativity with these proven workflow strategies.

Preparation Workflow

Pre-Performance Setup:

  1. Plan Your Set: Choose scenes that complement your musical progression
  2. Test All Scenes: Load each scene to verify they work correctly
  3. Check MIDI Mappings: Ensure all controllers are properly configured
  4. Prepare Transitions: Plan which scenes to use for different songs
  5. Create Backup Scenes: Have fallback options ready
  6. Document Your Setup: Note scene order and transition cues

Live Performance Strategies

During Performance:

  • Start Simple: Begin with familiar scenes, add complexity gradually
  • Use Contrast: Alternate between different visual styles
  • Match Energy: Align visual intensity with musical energy
  • Plan Transitions: Change scenes during musical transitions
  • Stay Flexible: Be ready to adapt to unexpected musical changes
  • Monitor Performance: Watch for frame rate drops or visual glitches

Creative Development Process

Building New Configurations:

  1. Start with Presets: Use existing presets as building blocks
  2. Experiment Freely: Try unexpected parameter combinations
  3. Document Discoveries: Save interesting configurations immediately
  4. Iterate Gradually: Make small changes and observe results
  5. Test with Music: Always test with actual musical content
  6. Save Variations: Create multiple versions of successful configurations

Organization Best Practices

Category Organization Strategy Benefits
File Naming Use consistent, descriptive names with categories Easy to find and identify configurations
Version Control Number versions and track changes over time Can revert to previous versions if needed
Documentation Include detailed descriptions and usage notes Remember purpose and context months later
Backup Strategy Regular backups of preset and scene libraries Protect against data loss and corruption

Collaboration Tips

  • Share Configurations: Export and share interesting presets/scenes with other performers
  • Document Requirements: Note any specific hardware or setup requirements
  • Use Standard Naming: Follow consistent naming conventions for shared files
  • Version Compatibility: Note which software version configurations were created with
  • Performance Context: Document the musical context and performance conditions
Pro Tips:
  • Regular Cleanup: Periodically review and organize your preset/scene libraries
  • Performance Testing: Always test new configurations under performance conditions
  • Backup Before Shows: Create backups before important performances
  • Learn from Others: Study and adapt configurations from other visual artists
  • Document Everything: Good documentation saves time and prevents confusion
